repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Health System
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, ratings indicate satisfactory
            project outcome and performances by the Bank and Borrower, a
            likely sustainability, though modest institutional
            development impacts. Often time, a project implementation
            imbedded in the Ministry of Health (MOH), rather than
            assigned to an independent project implementation unit
            (PIU), provides for better coordination, and increases
            ownership and likelihood of sustainability. Upon designing
            implementation structures, it is important to ensure that
            responsibility for implementation of each sub-component is
            clearly delineated, and, if a PIU structure is used, staff
            from relevant departments of the MOH be assigned
            responsibility for each component. Project design therefore,
            should be kept simple in an unstable political environment,
            and should match the client's implementation capacity,
            which is easily compromised under difficult political
            circumstances. Notwithstanding, with complex health
            management information system (HMIS) projects, it is
            essential that the client have capacity to manage the
            process, while programming and software development should
            be outsourced to a specialized reputable firm. Clinical
            guidelines are likely to be more effective if they are
            complemented by mechanisms to promote adherence, as well as
            incentives for compliance.

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Health System
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health System Development Project
            aims to enhance the management capacity of the Ministry of
            Health (MOH) and improve access to high-quality and
            affordable primary health care (PHC) services, especially in
            rural and underserved areas. There are four project
            components: 1) Upgrading primary health care network will
            replace the existing substandard Level II Primary Health
            Care (PHC) clinics (small community health centers) with PHC
            clinics of higher quality, which is part of the
            comprehensive Primary Health Care Rehabilitation Program. 2)
            The second component will establish a Health Management
            Information System, establish a health information center
            (HIC), finance the design and construction of the HIC
            facility, and support the capacity building of the HIC
            staff. 3) The third component will address the priority
            problem areas identified with respect to the quality and
            efficiency of health care. This include institutionalizing
            the Quality Improvement process, applying quality standards
            and procedures in selected priority health areas, drug
            rationalization, improving the quality and
            cost-effectiveness of treatment abroad cases, and
            strengthening MOH's capacity to monitor and evaluate
            the quality and efficiency of health services. 4) The last
            component will support the Project Implementation Unit for
            project coordination and management.
